block.p: U.S. and Vietnam Reach Broad Trade Agreement The United States and Vietnam have completed a trade agreement that would allow generally unfettered commerce between the two nations for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War, people involved in the negotiations said. Vietnamese and American officials reached the agreement after nearly four years of fitful negotiations.

Israel Cancels Disputed Sale Israel announced that it had canceled its sale of a sophisticated $250 million airborne radar system to China, a decision timed for the second day of the Camp David talks and intended to improve the mood in Congress, where heated opposition to the deal threatened aid to Israel.

Jail for an Israeli Politician The Israeli Supreme Court ruled that the leader of the Shas Party, Aryeh Deri, should be jailed for three years, upholding his conviction for bribery and fraud. After 10 years of investigations and litigation, the ruling dashed Mr. Deri's hopes of returning soon to the leadership of the Orthodox party.

Russia Car Executives Charged The Russian authorities brought tax evasion charges against top executives at the country's biggest carmaker as part of President Vladimir V. Putin's efforts to loosen the grip of Russia's richest men on the country's most profitable enterprises.

Mexican Party Regroups The leaders of the recently defeated governing party of Mexico, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, agreed on a formula to maintain internal discipline as its monopoly over power and wealth draws to a close.

Nigeria Struggles Against Fire Firefighters tried to douse burning pools of gasoline in southern Nigeria, struggling to extinguish a pipeline fire as villagers hastily buried charred bodies. While the cause of a fuel explosion on Monday is unclear, oil company executives said a fuel-smuggling ring had punctured the line to siphon gasoline.

Protestants Parade in Ireland More than 80,000 members of the Orange Order, Northern Ireland's once-dominant Protestant fraternal group, paraded through Belfast and 17 other towns in tense circumstances to commemorate the triumph of William of Orange over the Catholic James II in 1690.

Risks of Anti-H.I.V. Agent The United Nations warned that women at high risk of contracting the AIDS virus should not use nonoxynol-9, a widely sold spermicide, because it may increase the risk of H.I.V. rather than protect against it. Studies show that the spermicide is either ineffective or could even be harmful as an anti-H.I.V. agent.

DNA Fails to Exonerate Inmate Given Stay by Bush A DNA test has failed to exonerate a Texas death row inmate, Ricky Nolen McGinn, whose case took on political significance last month when Gov. George W. Bush interrupted his presidential campaign to grant him a stay of execution, according to officials knowledgeable about the results.

Chief Justice Impeached The New Hampshire House of Representatives impeached the chief justice of the State Supreme Court, David A. Brock, accusing him of ethical lapses on four grounds and handing his fate over to the State Senate for trial. The 253-to-95 vote on Chief Justice Brock culminated weeks of constitutional agony in the state.

Pentagon Cites Anthrax Failure Pentagon officials, in unusually blunt language, acknowledged the failure of their ambitious policy to inoculate all military personnel against the deadly anthrax virus.
Gore Courts Black Voters Al Gore summoned black voters to support his presidential candidacy, citing his long commitment to their cause and deriding Gov. George W. Bush as offering only words.

A foreign policy adviser to Governor Bush, in the days leading up to the Camp David peace talks, counseled Israeli officials to accept only a comprehensive peace agreement and to resist any efforts by the Clinton administration to use the summit in the presidential campaign.
Former Senator Bill Bradley indicated that he would endorse Vice President Gore when he appears with him today in their first joint appearance since Mr. Bradley quit the race in March.
Gays Rally in West Virginia Hundreds of gays and lesbians, blacks and whites, joined in Fairmont, W.Va., and demanded justice in behalf of Arthur Warren Jr., whose beaten body was found last week.

Assurances of Federal Inquiry Attorney General Janet Reno and other top Justice Department officials assured the Rev. Jesse Jackson that the department was actively investigating the hanging death of a black youth in his front yard in Mississippi a month ago.

Brooklyn Block Reeling In Aftermath of Explosion Residents roamed the block in Boerum Hill where a building was blown to bits on Tuesday, monitoring the fruitless rescue efforts and crying in each other's arms.

Three bodies were recovered from the rubble, and fire investigators said they strongly suspected that a gas leak had caused the blast. Officials suspect a leak in part because of the nature of the damage and the accounts of neighbors who said they smelled gas before the explosion.

New York City Spends More The Giuliani administration's emphasis on frugality has eased, according to budget monitors. As the city economy has flourished, government spending has accelerated over the last three years, growing at more than twice the rate of inflation.

Care Ordered at Rikers Jail A state judge ruled that the Giuliani administration must arrange for the continuing mental health care of thousands of inmates before they are released from Rikers Island.
Taking Bids to Restore Armory The state invited nonprofit organizations and private companies to submit proposals for rehabilitating and operating the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan.
Yankees Trade for Pitcher New York shipped a ransom in top prospects to the Cincinnati Reds for the left-hander Denny Neagle.

Robert Runcie The former archbishop of Canterbury was 78. He was considered a reform-minded if provocative churchman, known for his outspoken views on the royal family and the government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

Oil Producers' Profits Soar Higher gasoline prices have meant sharply higher profits for producers and refiners. Major oil companies are expected to post average earnings growth of 121 percent for the three months ended in June, compared with that period a year ago, and exploration and production companies are expected to report average increases of 371 percent.

Drug Maker to Settle Charges One of the world's largest producers of generic drugs, Mylan Laboratories, tentatively agreed to pay $147 million to settle accusations that it improperly cornered the market on raw materials for two widely prescribed drugs and then raised the price of those drugs, in some instances more than 3,000 percent.

Shift for Diamond Company De Beers Consolidated Mines, the diamond company that reigned as one of the most powerful monopolies of the last century, announced a major shift in the way it does business.
Nasdaq Index Rises Internet and other computer-related stocks surged, propelling the Nasdaq market to its biggest gain in more than five weeks and back into positive territory for the year.
Greenspan Offers Prescriptions Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested ways for preventing and coping with economic problems around the world.
Editorials: An Everglades action plan; building peace in Ulster; Governor Whitman's gaffe.
